PERFORMED AT THE LONDON AND DUBLIN THEATRES WITH UNIVERSAL APPLAUSE—AND AT GREENWICH-STREET, N. YORK.

P.HI: FIRST AMERICAN—FROM THE THIRD LONDON EDITION.

DIV1.P: NEW-YORK: PRINTED BY R. WILSON, 149, PEARL-STREET.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE—By a FRIEND, Spoken by Mr. WADDY.

LG.L: I COME not to announce a bashful Maid

L.HI: Who ne'er has try'd the drama's doubtful trade,
Who sees with flutt'ring hope the curtain rise,
And scans with timid glance your critic eyes;
My client is a more experienc'd dame,
Tho' not a Veteran, not unknown to Fame,
Who thinks your favours are an honest boast,
Yet fears to forfeit what she values most;
Who has, she trusts, some character to lose,
E'n tho' the woman did not aid the Muse;
Who courts with modest aim the public smile,
That stamp of merit, and that meed of toil.

LG.L: At Athens once (our author has been told)

L.HI: The Comic Muse, irregularly bold,
With living calumny profan'd her slage,
And forg'd the frailties of the faultless sage.
Such daring ribaldry you need not fear,
We have no Socrates to libel here.
Ours are the follies of an humbler flight,
Offspring of manners, volatile and light;
Our gen'ral satire keeps more knaves in awe,
Our court of conscience comes in aid of law.
Here scourg'd by wit, and pilloried by fun,

LG.L: Ten thousand coxcombs blush instead of one▪

L.HI: If scenes like these coul make the guilty shrink,
Could teach unfeeling Folly how to think,
Check Affectation's voluble career,
And from cold Fashion force the struggling tear,
Our wd your loudest praise forego,
Content to feel within "what passes show."
" But since" (she says) "such hopes cannot be mine,
" Such bold preensions I must needs rsign,
" Tell these great judges of dramatic laws,
" Their reformation were my best applause;
" Yet if the heart my proud appeal withstands,
" I ask the hmbler surage of their hands."

DIV1.HEAD: WIVES AS THEY WERE, AND MAIDS AS THEY ARE.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. An Apartment at Mr. Norberry's.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir William Dorrillon, followed by Mr. Norberry.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: WHY blame me?—Why blame me?—My sister had the sole management of your daughter by your own authority, from the age of six years, till within eight months of the present time, when, in conse∣quence of my sister's death, she was transferred to my pro∣tection.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Your sister, Mr. Norberry, was a prudent good woman—she never could instruct her in all this vice.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: —Depend upon it, my dear friend, that Miss Dorrillon, your daughter, came to my house just the same heedless woman of fashion you now see her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm. (impatiently.)
SP.P: Very well—'Tis very well—But when I think on my disappointment—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: There is nothing which may not be repaired, Maria, with you for a guide—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Me! She turns me into ridicule—laughs at me! This morning, as she was enumerating some of her frivolous expences, she observed me lift up my hands and sigh; on which she named ifty other extravagances she had no occasion to mention, merely to enjoy the pang which every folly of her's sends to my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P:
But do not charge this conduct of your daugh∣ter to the want of filial lov—did she know you were Sir
William Dorrillon, did she know you were her father, every word you uttered, every look you glanced, would be received with gentleness and submission:—but your present rebukes from Mr. Mandred (as you are called) from a perfect stran∣ger, as she supposes, she considers as an impertinence which she has a right to resent.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: I wish I had continued abroad. And yet, the hope of beholding her, and of bestowing upon her the riches I acquired, was my sole support through all the toils by which I gained them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: And, considering her present course of life, your riches could not come more opportunely.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: She shall never have a farthing of them. Do you think I have encountered the perils of almost every cli∣mate, to squander my hard-earned fortune upon the paltry vicious pleasures in which she delights? No—I have been now in your house exactly a month—I will stay but one day longer—and then, without telling her who I am, I will leave the kingdom and her for ever—Nor shall she know that this insignificant merchant whom she despises, was her father, till he is gone, never to be recalled.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: You are offended with some justice; but, as I have often told you, your excessive delicacy and respect for the conduct of the other sex, degenerate into rigour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: True—for what I see so near perfection as wo∣man, I want to see perfect. WE, Mr. Norberry, can never be perfect; but surely women, women, might easily be made angels!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: And if they were, we should soon be glad to make them into women again.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: (inattentive to Mr. Nor.)—She sets the example. She gives the fashion!—and now your whole house, and all your visitors, in imitation of her, treat me with levity, or with contempt.—But I'll go away to-morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: Can you desert your child in the moment she most wants your protection? That exquisite beauty just now mature—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: There's my difficulty!—There's my struggle!—If she were not so like her mother, I could leave her with∣out a pang—cast her off, and think no more of her—But that shape! that face! those speaking looks! Yet, how re∣versed!—Where is the diffidence, the humility—where is the simplicity of my beloved wife? Buied in her grave.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: And, in all this great town, you may never see even its apparition.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: I rejoice, however, at the stratagem by which I have gained a knowledge of her heart: deprived of the means of searching it in her early years, had I at present come as her father, she might have deceived me with counterfeit man∣ners, till time disclosed the imposition.—Now at least, I am not imposed upon.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Lord Priory.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Lord Priory!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: An old acquaintance of mine, though we sel∣dom meet. He has some singularities; and yet, perhaps—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: My dear Lord, I am glad to see you. Mr. Mandred (introducing Sir William). My Lord, I hope I see you in perfect health.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Yes: but in very ill humour. I came to London early this morning with my family for the winter, and found my house, after going through only a slight repair, so damp, that I dare not sleep in it: and so I am now sending and going all over the town to seek for lodgings.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: Then seek no farther, but take up your lodg∣ings here.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: To be plain with you, I called in hopes you would ask me; for I am so delicately scrupulous in respect to lady Priory that I could not bear the thought of taking her to an hotel.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: Then pray return home, and bring her hither immediately, with all your luggage.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: I am most extremely obliged to you (very fervently); for into no one house belonging to any of my ac∣quaintance would I take my wife, so soon as into yours. I have now been married eleven years, and during all that time I have made it a rule never to go on a visit▪ so as to domesti∣cate, in the house of a married man.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: May I enquire the reason of that?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: It is because I am married myself; and ha∣ving always treated my wife according to the ancient mode of treating wives, I would rather she should never be an eye∣witness to the modern household management

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: The ancients, I believe, were very affectionate

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: And they had reason to be so; for their wives obeyed them. The ancients seldom gave them the li∣berty to do wrong: but modern wives do as they like.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: And don't you suffer lady Priory to do as she likes?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Yes, when it is what I like too. But never, never else.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Does not this draw on you the character of an unkind husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory
SP.P: That I am proud of Did you never observe, that seldom a breach of sidelity in a wi is exposed, where the unfortunate husband is not said to be "he best creature in the world? Poor man, so good-natured?—Doatingly fond of his wife!—indulged her in every thing!—How cruel in her to serve him so!" Now, if I am served so, it shall not be for my good-nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: But I hope you equally disapprove of every severity.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory (rapidly)
SP.P: What do you mean by severity?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: You know you used to be rather violent in your temper.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: So I am still—apt to be hasty and passion∣ate—but that is rather of advantage to me as a husband—it causes me to be obeyed without hesitation—no liberty for contention, tears or repining. I insure conjugal sunshine; by now and then introducing a storm; while some husbands never see any thing but a cloudy sky, and all for want of a little domestic thunder to clear away the vapours.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: I have long conceived indulgence to be the bane of female happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: And so it is.—I know several women of fashion, who will visit six places of different amusement on the same night, have company at home besides, and yet, for want of something more, they'll be out of spirits; my wife never goes to a public place, has scarce ever company at home, and yet is always in spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Never visits operas, or balls, or routs?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: How should she? She goes to bd every night exactly at ten.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: In the name of wonder, how have you been able to bring her to that?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory
SP.P: By making her rise every morning at five.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: And so she becomes tired before night.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Tired to death. Or, if I see her eyes completely open at bed-time, and she asks me to play one game more at picquet, the next morning I jog her elbow at half after four.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: But suppose she does not reply to the signal?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Then I turn the key of the door when I leave the chamber; and there I ind her when I come home in the evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: And without her having seen a creature all day?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: That is in my favour; for not having seen a single soul, she is rejoiced even to see me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: And will she speak to you after such usage?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: If you only considered how much a wo∣man longs to speak after being kept a whole day silent, you would not ask that question.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: Well, this is the most surprising method!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Not at all. In ancient days when man∣ners were simple and pure, did not wives wait at the table of their husbands? and did not angels witness the subordination? I have taught Lady Priory to practise the same humble do∣cile obedience—to pay respect to her husband in every shape and every form—no careless inattention to me—no smiling politeness to others in preference to me—no putting me up in a corner—in all assemblies, she considers her hus∣band as the first person.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: I am impatient to see her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: But don't expect a fine lady with high feathers, and the et caetera of an Eastern concubine; you will see a modest plain Englishwoman with a cap on her head▪ a handkerchief on her neck, and a gown of her own manu∣facture.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: My friend Norberry, what a contrast must there be between Lady Priory and the ladies in this house!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory (starting)
SP.P: Have you ladies in this house!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: Don't be alarmed; they are both single, and can give Lady Priory no ideas concerning the marriage state.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Are you sure of that? Some single wo∣men are more informed than their friends wish them to be.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: For these ladies, notwithstanding a few (what you would call) excesses, I will answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Well, then, I and my wife will be with you about nine in the evening; you know we go to bed at ten.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: But remember you bring your own servants to wait on you at five in the morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: I shall bring but one—my old servant Oliver, who knows all my customs so well, that I never go any where without him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: And is that old servant your valet still?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: No, he is now a kind of gentleman in wait∣ing. I have had no employment for a valet since I married:—my wife, for want of dissipation, has not only time to attend upon herself, but upon me. Do you think I could suffer a clumsy man to tie on my neckcloth or comb out my hair, when the soft, delicate, and tender hands of my wife are at my command?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: After this amiable description of a woman, how can I endure to see her, whom reason bids me detest; but whom nature still—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: Here she comes; and her companion in folly along with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: There's another woman! that Lady Mary Raffle! How can you suffer such people in your house?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: She is only on a visit for a few months—she comes every winter, as her family and mine have long been intimately connected.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Let us go. I can't bear the sight of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: Stay, and for once behave with politeness and good humour to your daughter—do—and I dare venture my life, she will neither insult nor treat you with disrespect. You know you always begin first.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Have not I a right to begin first?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: But that is a right of which she is ignorant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: And deserves to be so, and ever shall be so, I stay and treat her with politeness and good humour? No—rather let her kneel and implore my pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: Suffer me to reveal who you are, and so she will.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: If you expose me only by one insinuation to her knowledge, our friendship is that moment at an end.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor. (Firmly).
SP.P: I have already given you my pro∣mise on that subject; and you may rely upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: I thank you—Let us go, I believe you—and I thank you.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lady Mary Raffle and Miss Dorrillon.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.STAGE: (Stealing on as Mr. Norberry and Sir William leave the stage).
SP.P: They are gone. Thank heaven they are gone out of this room, for I expect a dozen visitors; and Mr. Norberry looks so gloomy upon me, he puts me out of spirits; while that Mr. Mandred's peevishness is not to be borne.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Be satisfied; for you were tolerably severe upon him this morning in your turn.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Why, I am vext—and I don't like to be found fault with in my best humour, much less when I have so many things to tease me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: What are they?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: I have now lost all my money, and all my jew∣els at play; it is almost two years since I have received a single remittance from my father; and Mr. Norberry refuses to advance me a shilling more. What I shall do to discharge a debt which must be paid either to-day or to-morrow heaven knows! Dear Lady Mary, you could not lend me a small sum, could you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Who? I! [with surprise]—My dear creature, it was the very thing I was going to ask of you: for when you have money, I know no one so willing to disperse it among her friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Am not I!—I protest I love to part with my money; for I know with what pleasure I receive it myself, and I like to see that joy sparkle in another's eye, which has so often brightened my own. But last night ruined me—I must have money somewhere.—s you can't assist me, I must ask Mr. Norberry for his carriage, and immediately go in search of some friend that can lend me four, or five, or six, or seven hundred pounds. But the worst is, I have lost my credit—Is not that dreadful?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I know what it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: What will become of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Why don't you marry, and throw all your misfortunes upon your husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Why don't you marry? For you have as ma∣ny to throw as I have.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: But not so many lovers who would be wil∣ling to receive the load. I have no Sir George Evelyn with ten thousand pounds a year—no Mr. Bronzely.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: If you have not now, you once had: for I am sure Bronzely once paid his addresses to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: And you have the vanity to suppose you took him from me?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Silence.—Reserve your anger to deend, and not to attack me. We should be allies by the common ties of poverty: and 'tis time to arm; for here's the enemy.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir William and Mr. Norberry.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: They are here still.
SP.STAGE: (Aside to Mr. Norberry, and offering to go back.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: (Preventing him.) No, no.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: I have been waiting here, Mr. Norberry, to ask a favour of you.
Will you be so kind as to lend me your carriage for a couple of hours?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor. Mr. Mandred
SP.P: has just asked me for it to take him into the city.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Oh, Mr. Mandred will give it up to Miss Dorrillon, I am sure; he can defer his business till to-morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: No Madam▪ she may as well put off hers. I have money to receive, and I can't do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: I have money to pay, and I can't do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: If one is going to receive, and the other to pay money, I think the best way is for you to go together; and then, what deficiency there is on one side, the other may supply.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Will you consent, Mr. Mandred?—Come, do; and I'll be friends with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: "She'll be friends with me!"

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Will you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Well. I certainly can ask a favour of Mr. Mandred better than I can of any person in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: Why so, Maria?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Because, instead of pain, I can see it gives him pleasure to refuse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: I never confer a favour, of the most trivial kind, where I have no esteem.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Nor would I receive a favour, of the most trivial kind, from one who has not liberality to esteem me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: Come, Miss Dorrillon, do not grow serious: laugh as much as you please, but say nothing that—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: From whom then can you ever receive favours, except from the vain, the idle, and the depraved?—from those whose lives are passed in begging them of others?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: They are the persons who know best how to bestow them: for my part, had I not sometimes felt what it was to want a friend, I might never have had humanity to be the friend of another.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Servant.
SP.P: Sir George Evelyn.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: And pray, my dear, whose friend have you ever been?—
—Not Sir George Evelyn's, I am sure; and yet he of all others deserves your friendship most.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: But friendship will not content him: as soon as he thought he had gained that—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: He aspired to the supreme happiness of your love.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Now you talk of "supreme happiness," have you provided tickets for the fete on Thursday?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: I have; provided you have obtained Mr. Norberry's leave to go.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: That I cannot grant.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Nay, my dear Sir, do not force me to go without it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Would you dare?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: "Would I dare," Mr. Mandred!—and what have you to say if I do?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: I was only going to say, that if you did, and I were Mr. Norberry—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: And if you were Mr. Norberry, and treated me in the manner you now do, depend upon it should not think your approbation or disapprobation, your pleasure or displeasure, of the slightest consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: (Greatly agitated.) I dare say not—I dare say not. Good morning, Sir George—I dare say not.—Good morning, Mr. Norberry.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: Slopt a moment.—Maria, you have offended Mr. Mandred.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: He has offended me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: I shan't offend you long.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.STAGE: (Going to him, and taking him by the arm)
SP.P: Stay, Mr. Mandred: Miss Dorrillon, make an apology; Mr. Mandred is my friend, and you must not treat him with this levity.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: No, no apology.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: No, no apology▪ But I'll tell you what I'll do.

—If Mr. Mandred likes, I'll shake hands with him—and we'll be good friends for the future. But then, don't find fault with me—I can't bear it. You don't like to be found fault with, yourself—You look as cross as any thing every time I say the least word against you. Come, shake hands; and don't let us see one another's fail∣ings for the future.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: There is no future for the trial.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: How do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: Mr. Mandred sets off again for India to-mor∣row.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Indeed! I thought he was come to live in England! I am sorry you are going.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Why sorry?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Because we have so frequently quarrelled. I am always unhappy when I am going to be parted from a person with whom I have disagreed; I often think I could part with less regret from a friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Not, I suppose, if the quarrel is forgiven?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Ah! but Mr. Mandred does not forgive! no! in his looks I can always see resentment—Some∣times indeed I have traced a spark of kindness, and have gent∣ly tried to blow it to a little flame of friendship; when, with one hasty puff I have put it out.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: You are right. It is—I believe—extinguished.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: A very singular man.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Oh! if he was not rich, there would be no bearing him—indeed he seems to have lost all his friends; for during the month he has been here, I never found he had any one acquaintance out of this house.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P:
And what is very strange, he has taken an aversion to me.—But it is still more strange, that although I
know he has, yet in my heart I like him. He is morose to an insufferable degree; but then, when by chance he speaks kind, you cannot imagine how it soothes me.—He wants com∣passion and all the tender virtues; and yet, I frequently think, that if any serious misfortune were to beal me, he would be the first person to whom I should fly to complain.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Then why don't you ly and tell him of your misfortune last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George
SP.P: What misfortune?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Hush!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: A loss at play.—
—I beg your pardon, but it was out before you said hush.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Ah! Maria, will you still risk your own and my happiness?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Your happiness and mine, Sir!—I beg you will not place them so near to each other.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Mine is so firmly fixed on you, it can only exist in yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Then, when she is married to Mr. Bronze∣ly, you will be happy because will be so?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Bronzely! has he dared?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Have not you dared, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: But I believe Mr. Bronzely is the most dar∣ing of the two.—
—Take care of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Miss Dorrillon, I will not affront you by sup∣posing that you mean seriously to receive the addresses of Mr. Bronzely; but I warn you against giving others, who know you less than I do, occasion to think so.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: I never wish to deceive any one—I do admit of Mr. Bronzely's addresses.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Why, he is the professed lover of your friend Lady Mary! or granting he denies it, and that I even pass over the frivolity of the coxomo, still he is unworthy of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: He says the same of you; and half a dozen more say exactly the same of each other. If you like, I'll discard every one of you as unworthy; but if I retain you, I will retain the rest. Which do you choose?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: I submit to any thing rather than the total loss of you—But remember, that your felicity—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P:
"Felicity! felicity!"—ah! that is a word
not to be found in the vocabulary of my sensations!—sighing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: I believe you, and have always regarded you with a compassion that has augmented my love. In your in∣fancy, deprived of the watchful eye and anxious tenderness of a mother; the manly caution and authority of a father; misled by the brilliant vapour of fashion; surrounded by enemies in the garb of friends—Ah! do you weep? bles∣sed, blessed be the sign! Suffer me to dry those tears I have caused, and to give you a knowledge of true felicity.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: I am very angry with myself.—Don't, I beg, tell Mr. Norberry or Mr. Mindred you saw me cry—they'll suppose I have been more indiscreet ( her tears) than I really have. For in reality I have no∣thing—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George,
SP.P: Do not endeavour to conceal from me, what my tender concern for you has given me the means to become acquainted with. I know you are plunged in difficulties by your father neither sending nor coming, as you once expected—I know you are still deeper plunged in your fondness for play.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Very well, Sir—proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Thus, then—Suffer me to send my steward to you this morning; he shall regulate your accounts, and place them in a state that shall protect you from further embar∣rassment till your father sends to you; or protect you from his reproaches, should he arrive.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Sir George, I have listened to your detail of vices which I acknowledge, with patience, with humility—but your suspicion of those which I have not, I treat with pride, with indignation.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George,
SP.P: How! suspicion!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: What part of my conduct, Sir, has made you dare to suppose I would extricate myself from the difficulties that surround me, by the influence I hold over the weakness of a lover?

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. Another Apartment at Mr. Norberry's.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter two porters from an upper entrance, bringing in trunks; Lord Priory and Mr. Norberry following.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P:
HERE, Stephens, why are you out of the
way? Shew the men with these boxes into the dressing-room appointed for my Lord Priory.
SP.STAGE: (A servant enters on the opposite side, and the porters follow him off at a lower entrance on that side)

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir William Dorrillon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: My Lord, I hope I see you well this evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Yes, Sir—and you find I have literally ac∣cepted Mr. Norberry's invitation, and am come to him with my luggage.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Oliver, with a small box in each hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory,
SP.P: Follow those men with the trnks, Oliver.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: Ah, Mr. Oliver, how do you do?

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver,
SP.P: Pretty well—tolerably well! I thank you, Sir.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory (to her)
SP.P: Mr. Norberry, our worthy host; and Mr. Mandred

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: I hope your ladyship will find my house so little inconvenient to you, as to induce you to make no very short visit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: I have no doubt, Sir, but I shall find, from your friendship, every comfort in this house which it is possible for me to enjoy out of my own.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lady Mary Raffle and Miss Dorrillon.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: Lady Priory—Lady Mary Raffle—Miss Dorrillon—Lord Priory.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Permit me, Lady Priory, to take you to the next room: we are going to have tea immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: I have drank tea, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Already! It is only nine o'clock.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Then it is near my hour of going to bed.
SP.STAGE: (Lord Priory, Sir William, and Mr. Norberry, retire to the back of the stage, and talk apart.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Go to bed already! in the name of won∣der, what time did you rise this morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Why, I do think it was almost six o'clock.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary
SP.P: And were you up at six this morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory,
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: At six in the month of January!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: It is not light till eight: and what good, now could you possibly be doing for two hours by candle-light?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Pray, Lady Mary, at what time did you go to bed?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: About three this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: And what good could you possibly be do∣ing for eleven hours by candle-light?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Good! It's as much as can be expected from a woman of fashion▪ if she does no harm.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: But I should fear you would do a great deal of harm to your health, your spirits, and the tranquillity of your mind.
SP.STAGE: [Mr. Norberry goes off—Lord Priory and Sir William come forward.]

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Oh, my Lord Priory, I realy find all the accounts I have heard of your education for a wife to be actu∣ally true!—and I can't help laughing to think, if you and I chanced to have married together, what a different creature you most likely would have made of me, to what I am at present!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Yes; and what a different creature you most likely would have made of me, to what I am at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Lady Priory I am not accustomed to pay com∣pliments, or to speak my approbation, even when praise is a just tribute; but your virtues compel me to an eulogium.—That wise submission to a husband who loves you, that cheerful smile so expressive of content, and that plain dress which indicates the elegance as well as the simplicity, of your mind, are all symbols of a heart so unlike to those which the present fashion of the day has misled—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Why look so stedfastly on me, Mr. Man∣dred? Do you pretend to see my heart?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Have you any?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Yes; and one large enough to hold—even my enemy.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Servant.
SP.P: Mr. Bronzely.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Shew him into the other room.
Come, Lady Priory we must introduce you to Mr. Bronzely: he is one of the most fashionable, agreeable, plea∣sant, whimsical unthinking, and spirited creatures in all the world: you'll be charmed—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: I dare a it's near ten o'clock. I am afraid I shan't be able to keep awake.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: You must—We are going to have a little con∣cert—'Twill be impossible to sleep.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Upon my word, my Lord, your plan of management has made your wife unfit for company.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: So much more fit to be a wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: She is absolutely fatigued with hard labour—for shame!—How does household drudgery become her hand?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Much better than cards and dice do yours.
SP.STAGE: [Exit Lady Mary followed by Lord Prior,—Sir William is left on the stage alone.]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: She "has a heart large enough to receive her enemy."—And by that enemy she menas her father.
SP.STAGE: [He sits down, and shew marks of inquietude. Enter Sir George Evelyn.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: I beg your pardon, Mr. Mandred—I hope I don't interrupt you—I only wished to speak to Miss Dor∣rillon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: She is just gone into the next room,

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: To the concert?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Are not you invited?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Yes; but before I go in, I wish to know who are the company.—Can you tell whether—a Mr. Bron∣zely is there?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: I know he is.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Are you acquainted with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: I have met him here frequently.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: And are you certain he is here at present?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: I have reason to be certain.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Any particular reason?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Your mistress, when his name was announced, went out to him, exclaiming "he was the most charming and accomplished man in the world."

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George
SP.P: She loves him, Sir—I have reason to believe—to know she loves him. Thus she gives up my happiness and her own, to gratify the vanity of a man who has no real regard for her; but whose predominant pas∣sion is to enjoy the villanous name of a general seducer.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Why do you suffer it?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Huh! Don't repeat what I have said, or I lose her for ever. I am at present under her resentment; and have just sent into the next room, to ask, if she were there, to speak with her.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Miss Dorrillon.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dorrillon.
SP.P: And is it possible I was sent for by you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Don't be offended, that I should be uneasy and

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: I can't forgive you, Sir, 'ti impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: You pardon those, a, who offend you more.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: But an ungrateful mind always prefers the un∣worthy.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Ah, Mr. Mandred, are you there? (playfully And have you undertaken to be sir George's counsel? If you have, I believe he must lose his cause. To fit you for the tender task of advocate in love,—have you ever been admitted an honourable member of that court? Have you, with all that solemn wisdom of which you are master, studied Ovid, as our great laywers study Blackstone? If you have—shew cause—why plaintiff has a right to defendant's heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: A man of fortune, of family, and of character, ought at least to be treated with respect, and with honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: You mean to say, That A is beloved by B, why should not A be constrained to return B's love? Counsellor for defendant—Because, moreover, and besides B who has a claim on defendant's heart, there are also C, D, E, F, and G; all of whom put in their separate claims—and what, in this case, can poor A do? She is willing to part and divide her love, share and share alike; But B will have all or none: so poor A must remain A by herself A

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Do you think I would accept of a share of your heart!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Do you think I could afford to give it you all? "Besides," says defendant's counsellor, I will prove that plaintiff B has no heart to give defendant in return—he has, indeed, a pulsation on the left side; but as it never beat with any thing but suspicion and jealousy; in the laws of love, it is not termed, admitted, or considered a heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Geoege.
SP.P: Where are you going?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: To the music-room, to be sure: and if you fol∣low me, it shall be to see me treat every person there better than yourself—and Mr. Bronzely, whom you hate to see me treat him best of all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: I must follow you, though to death.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P:
Fool,—and yet am not I neary as weak as he is? Else why do inger in this house? Why feed my hopes with some propitious moment to waken her to repentance? Why anxiously wish to ward off some dreadful fate?—If she would marry sir George, now—if she would give me
only one proof of discretion, I think I would endeavour to take her to my heart.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mr. Bronzely, in great haste.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: My dear sir, will you do me the greatest favour in the world?—You must do it in an instant too. Do, my dear sir, ask no questions; but lend me your coat for a single moment, and take mine—only for a moment—I cannot explain reasons now, my impatience is so great;—but, the instant you have complied, I will inform you of the whole secret; and you will for ever rejoice that you granted my request.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: (aside, with great scorn.) And this very con∣temptible fellow is the favoured lover of my daughter!—I'll—(after a struggle)—yes—I'll make myself master of his secret—it may possibly concern her—my child—my child's safety may depend upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Dear Mr. Mandred, no time is to be lost!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: This is rather a strange request, Mr. Bron∣zely. However, your fervency convinces me you must have some very forcible reason.—There's my coat, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Thank you, dear Sir, a thousand times.—This goodness I shall forever remember—This binds me to you forever!—(putting it on.) Thank you, Sir, a thousand times!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: (after putting on the other coat.) And now, Sir, explain the cause of this metamorphosis—let me have the satisfaction to know what advantage will accrue from it; and in what I have to rejoice.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Will you promise me not to reveal the secret, if I trust you with it?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Would you add conditions after the bargain is made? I must know your secret instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Then I will disclose it to you voluntarily; and rely on your honour to keep it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: (attentively.) Well, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Hark! I thought I heard somebody coming!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: I insist upon the information.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P:
Well, then, Sir—well—you shall—you shall.—Then, Sir—in the small gallery, which separates the music-room from the rest of these apartments—in that little
gallery, the lamp, unfortunately, is just gone out.—I was (as unfortunately) coming along, when the whisking of a woman's gown made me give a sudden start!—I found a person was in the gallery with me, and in the dark.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Well▪ Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: And so, confidently assuring myself, that it was Miss Dorrillon's waiting-maid, or Lady Mary's waiting-maid, I most unluckily clasped my arms around her, and took one kiss.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Only one?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: There might be half a dozen! I won't pre∣tend to swear to one. We'll say half a dozen, before I knew who she was. My rapidity would not let her breathe at first, and she was fairly speechless. But the moment she recovered her breath, she cry'd, "Villain! whoever you are, you will repent this;"—and I found it was the voice of a lady to whom I had just been introduced in the concert-room, one Lady Pri∣ory—It seems she was stealing to bed at the time we unhap∣pily met.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: But what has this to do with your coat?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: A great deal, sir—you will find a great deal.—As I perceived she did not know me, I carefully held my tongue—but she, with her prudish notions, called "Help!" and "Murder!" On which, I flew to the door, to get away before the lights could be brought—she flew after me; and, as I went out, exclaimed—Don't hope to conceal yourself: I shall know you among the whole concert-room; for I carry scissors hanging at my side, and I have cut a piece off your coat.—[Sir William looks hastily at his coat—on which Bron∣zely holds up the part cut▪]—and sure enough, so she had!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: (in anger.) And what, sir, am I to have the disgrace—

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Either you or I must.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: And do you dare—

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Consider, my dear sir, how much less the ault is, if perpetrated by you, than by me! This is the first of∣fence of the kind which, I dare say, you have committed this many a year; and it will be overlooked in you. But I have been suspected of two or three things of the same sort within a very short time; and I should never be forgiven.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Nor ought you to be forgiven—it would be scandalous in me to connive—

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P:
But would it not be more scandalous to reveal
the secret of a person who confided in you?—who flew to you in distress, as his friend, the partner of his cares?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Your impertinence to me, but more your of∣fence to a woman of virtue, deserves punishment. Yet I think the punishment of death, in the way that a man of my Lord Priory's temper might inflict it, much too honourable for your deserts; so I save your life for some less creditable end. I lend you my coat, to disgrace you by existence; and will go to my chamber, and put on another mself. (Passes Bronzel, in order to retire to his chamber.)

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lord Priory, who meets him. Sir Wm. starts.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: [going up to Lord Priory.) Ah, my Lord! is the concert over? charming music! that solo was divine.

SP.SPEAKER: [Sir Wm.
SP.P: steals to a chair, and sits down to hide his coat.]

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory
SP.P: [after looking inquisitively at Bronzely's dress.] It is time the concert should be over—it had been better it had never begun; for there have been some very improper persons admitted. [In great anger.]

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: [affecting surprise.] Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory
SP.P: (trembling with rage) I am at a loss how to act. (Draws a chair with violence, and places himself down by Sir William—Sir William appears disconcerted and uneasy.) But if I could find the man to whom this piece of cloth belongs—

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: What! this small piece of woolen cloth?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Yes, then I should know how to act. In the mean time, Mr Mandred, as I know you are a great ad∣mirer of my wife [Sir William starts], and a grave prudent man of honour, I come to ask your advice, how I am the most likely to find out the villain who has dared to insult her; for a gross insult she has received from one of Mr. Norberry's vi∣sitors, wearing a coat of which this is a part.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: The villain, no doubt, stole out of the house immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: I ordered the street door to be guarded that instant—and you, Mr. Bronzely, are now the last man whose habit I have examined.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: And you see I am perfectly whole. [turning round.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: I do see—I do see. [Sir William moves about on his chair, and appears greatly embarrassed. Lord Pri∣ory starts up in a violent passion—Sir William starts up with him.]

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: I'll find him out if he is on earth—I'll find him out if—My passion carries me away—I have not coolness to detect him myself—I'll employ another—I'll send Oliver in search. Oliver! [calling] Oliver! here, Oli∣ver! Why don't you answer when you are called, you stupid, dull, idle, forgetful, blundering, careless, self-sufficient—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: (rising with great dignity.) And now, Mr. Bronzely, how do you think you are to repay me, for having fet one transitory moment of shame? Understand, Sir, that shame is one of the misfortunes to which I have never—

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lady Mary.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely
SP.P: (Aside to Sir Wm) Sit down, sit down—sit down—hold your tongue, and sit down.
SP.STAGE: [Sir William reluctantly retires to his chair.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Well, I do most cordially rejoice, when peevish, suspicious, and censorious people, meet with humi∣liation! I could die with laughing at the incident which has put both my Lord and my Lady Priory into the greatest ter∣ror, grief, and rage.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: (rising.) I am out of all patience. The malicious depravity of persons in a certain sphere of life is not to be borne. [With firmness and solemnity.] Lady Mary—Mr. Bronzely—

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely
SP.P: (in a half whisper to him.) Go away—don't expose yourself—steal out of the room—take my advice, and go to bed—hide yourself. So great is my respect for you, I would not have you detected for the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: I am going to retire, sir. I would not throw my friend's house into confusion and broils; therefore I am as well pleased not to be detected as you can be. (Goes to the door, then turns.) But before I quit the room, I am irresisti∣bly impelled to say—Mr. Bronzely! Lady Mary! while you continue to ridicule all that is virtuous, estimable, digni∣fied, your vices most assuredly will plunge you into that very disgrace—

DIV3.STAGE: (Enter Oliver, and places the piece of cloth against Sir Wil∣liam's coat.)

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: 'Tis as exact a match as ever was—it fits to a thread. Ha, ha, ha!—Ha, ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Rascal!

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Did not I entreat you to go to-bed!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Oh! this is the highest gratification I ever knew. My Lord! my Lord! (calling.)

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Hush, hush!—hold, for heaven's sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: But mercy and goodness defend us! who would have thought of this grave gentleman? Ha, ha, ha!—I can tell you what, sir; my Lord will be in a terrible passion with you. This house won't hod you both; and I am sure I hate to make mischief.—Mum—I'll say nothing about it. (clapping Sir William on the shoulder.) And so make your∣self eas.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely
SP.P: (on the other side of Sir William.) Yes, make yourself easy.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver▪
SP.P: A good servant should sometimes be a peace∣maker—for my part, I have faults of my own, and so, I dare say, has that gentleman—and so, I dare say, has that gentlewoman. But of all the birds in the wood, how came you to make up to my Lady? Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: No jests—no jests. Mr. Mandred is my best friend.—and he is not so much to bame as you think, for—Good night, my dear sir. Heaven bless you. I thank you a thousand times. Good night. (Shaking hands with Sir William, and leading him towards the door)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: (with steady composure) Good night. Good night. Lady Mary.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Why, he never so much as once said he was o∣bliged to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: I am sure, if you do not discover this to your master, I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Oh! as that old gentleman had not manners to say "thank you for your kindness," I'll go tell my Lord di∣rectly.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: (running after him.) No, no, no—stop Oliver. He is gone!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: What makes you thus anxious and concer∣ned, Bronzely? Now, I wish I may suffer death, if, til I came into this room, I did not think you were the offender.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: indeed!—No, if I could have been tempted to offend any woman in this house in a similar man∣ner, it could have been none but you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P:
No, Bronzely, no; I have been too par∣tial
to you, to have any remaining claims—Hark! don't I hear Lord Priory's voice in a dreadful rage?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Then Oliver has accused him▪ What shall I do to prevent mischief? Dear Lady Mary, as it is not pro∣per for me to stay here any onger uninvited, do you run and try to pacify my Lord Priory. Te him Mandred does not sleep here to-night; and in the morning you are sure he will make an apology.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: I will do as you desire—but I know Mr. Mandred so well, that I am sure he will not.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Then I will for him. Early in the morning, I'll wait on Lady Priory, and beg pardon in his name without his knowing it. Yes, I have got poor Mandred into a dif∣ficulty, and it is my duty to get him out of it. And then, I shall not only serve him, but have one interview more with that heavenly woman.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. An Apartment at Mr. Norberry's.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mr. Bronzely, followed by a servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely
SP.P: (looking at his watch.) I am early, I know—but Lady Priory is the only person I wish to see. Is my Lord with her?

SP.SPEAKER: Servant.
SP.P: No, sir, Lord Priory sat up very late, and is in bed yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Acquaint Lady Priory a person who comes on urgent business, begs to speak with her. If she asks my name, you know it. (Exit Servant.) Pray heaven she may bless me with her sight: Never was so enchanted b a woman in my life—and never was played such a trick in my life▪ I am half inflamed b love, and half by spite, once more to attempt her.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lady Priory—he bows most respectfully, she curses.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Lady Priory, I come—I come upon rather an a ward, yet a very serious business: it was my misfortune to be among that company yesterday evening, where an un∣worthy member of it had the insolence to offer an affnt to your resplendent virtue—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: I have some household accounts to arrange, and breakfast to make for my Lord as soon as he his ; therefore, if you please, Sir proceed to the bu∣siness n which you came, without thinking it necessary to in∣terrupt it by any compliment to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: I will be concise, Madam.—In a word▪ I wait upon you from Mr. Mandred, with the most humble apology for his late conduct, which he acknowledges to have been indecorous and unwarrantable: but he trusts, that in consequence of the concession which I now make for him, the whole matter wi, from this hour, be buried in oblivion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory
SP.P: [going to the side of the scene, and speaking.] If my Lord is at leisure, tel him here is a gentleman would be glad to speak with him.—To Bronzely. I am sorry, Sir, you should know so little of the rules of our family, as to sup∣pose that I could give an answer upon any subject in which my husband condescends to be concerned.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Lady Priory, stop. You can at least use your power to soften Lord Priory's resentment; and unless this apology is accepted, a challenge must follow, and possibly he may fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Possibly. [Sighing.]

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: You are interested for your husband's life?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Certainly. But I set equal value on his reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Hear me one sentence more—I cannot part from her. Aside] Oh I have something of such im∣portance to communicate to you—and yet—I know not how!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Then te it to my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Hem, hem. Aside]. Oh! Lady Priory, if the insult of last night has given you offence, should you not wish to be informed of a plan laid for yet greater violence?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Good heaven!

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely▪
SP.P: This is neither time nor place to disclose what I wish to say—nor do I know how to find an opportunity to speak with you alone, free from the possibility of intrusion; where I could revea a secret to you, which is connected with your happiness, with your future peace,

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: You alarm me beyond expression. I am going to my own house about twelve o'clock, for a couple of hours—follow me there.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: And I shall be admitted?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Certain—for you have excited my cu∣riosity, and I am all impatience to hear what you have to com∣municate that so much concerns me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Promise then, no person but yourself shall ver know of it. [She hesitates.] Unless you promise this, I

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: [after a second hesitation] I do promise—I promise faithfully.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Your word is sacred, I rely.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Most sacred.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: And you promise that no one but yourself shall know of the appointment we have now made at your house, nor of the secret which I will then disclose to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: I promise faithfully that no one but myself shall ever know of either.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Remember then to be there alone, exactly—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: At one o'clock.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: And that your servants have orders to shew me to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: I am too much interested to forget one cir∣cumstance.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Go now then to Lord Priory with Mandred's apology—and arge his acceptance of it, with all that persua∣sion by which you are formed to govern, while you appear to obey.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: I will present the apology as I received it from you; but do not imagine I dare give my opinion upon it, unless I am desired.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: But if you are desired, you will then say—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Exactly what I think.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: I'll do a meritorious act this very day. This poor woman lives in slavery with her husband. I'll give her an opportunity to run away from him. When we meet, I'll have a post-chaise waiting a few doors from her house; boldly tell her that I love her; and—(Enter Miss Dorrillon.)—My dear Miss Dorrillon, I could not sleep all night, but am come thus early on purpose to complain of your treatment of me during the whole of yesterday evening. Not one look did you glance towards me—and there I sat in miserable solitude up in one corner the whole time of the concert.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: I protest I did not see you!—and, stranger still! never thought of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: You then like another better than you do me?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Do you tell him so?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: You tell him you like me the best.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P:
Then I will believe what you say to him, and
not what you say to me.—And though you charge me with inconstancy, yet I swear to you, my beloved Maria, (taking her hand) that no woman, no woman but yourself—

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir William, and starts at seeing his Daughter in such close conversation with Bronzely.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William
SP.P: (aside.) How familiar!—My eyes could not be shocked with a sight half so wounding to my heart as this!

SP.SPEAKER: Hush!
SP.P: you have heard the story; but don't laugh at him now. He is in a devilish ill humour, and it will all fall on me. Go away.—It's a very good story, but laugh at him another time.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: I don't believe a word of the story; yet, as a received opinion, it is a charming weapon for an enemy, and I long to use it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Not now, not now—because I have some bu∣siness with him, and 'twill put him out of temper. (He hands her to the door)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm
SP.P: (Looking stedfastly after her.) Poor girl! Poor girl! I am not yet sufficiently enraged against her, not to compassi∣onate her for her choice!—Is this the man who is to be, for life, her companion, her protector?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Well, Mr Mandred, I believe I have settled it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Settled what? (anxiously)

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: At least I have done all in my power to serve you; perhaps you don't know that Mr. Oliver divulged the whole affair. But I have waited on my Lady Priory, and I do believe I have settled it with her, to manage it so with my Lord, that every thing shall be huhed up. You may expect a few jests among your female acquaintance, and a few epigas in the news-papers; but I verily believe every thing material is safe.—Is there any farther satisfaction which you demand from me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: Not at present—a man is easily satisfied who possesses both courage and strength to do himself right, whenever he feels his wrongs oppressive. I have as yet found but little inconvenience from the liberties you have taken with me; and what, just at this time, far more engages my atten∣tion than revenge, is an application to you for intelligence. Without farther preface, do you pay your addresses to the young lady who lives in this house?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Yes I do, Sir—I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: You know, I suppose, which of the two ladies I mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Which ever you mean Sir 'its all the same; for I pay my addresses to them both.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William
SP.P: [starting.] To them both!

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: I always do.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: And pray, which of them do you love?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Both, Sir—upon my word, both—I assure you, both.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: But you don't intend to marry both?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: I don't intend to marry either: and indeed, the woman whom I love best in the world, has a husband already. Do you suppose I could conine my affections to Lady Mary or Miss Dorrillon, after Lady Priory appeared? do you suppose I did not know who it was I met last night in the dark? wherever I visit, Mr. Mandred, I always make love to every woman in the house: and I assure you they all expect it—I assure you, Sir, they all expect it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Have you any further commands for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: Yes, one word more—And you really have no regard for this girl who parted from you as I came in?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Oh yes, pardon me—I admire, I adore, I love her to distraction: and if I had not been so long ac∣quainted with my Lady Mary, nor had seen my Lady Priory last night, I should certainly call Sir George Evelyn to an account for being so perpetually with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William
SP.P: (anxiously.) Do you think he loves her?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Yes, I dare say, as well as I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: Do you think she likes him?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: I think she likes me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: But, with your method of affection, she may like him too.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: She may, she may—In short, there is no an∣swering for what she likes—all whim and flightiness—acquaint∣ed with every body—conquetting with every body—and in debt with every body. Her mind distracted between the claims of lovers, and the claims of creditors,—the anger of Mr. Norberry, and the want of intelligence from her father!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: She is in a hopeful way.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P:
Oh, it would be impossible to think of marry∣ing
her in her present state—for my part, I can't—and I ques∣tion whether Sir George would—But if her father come home, and give her the fortune that was once expected, why then I may posbly marry her myself

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William
SP.P: (firmly.) She will never have any fortune—I came from India lately, you know; and you may take my word her father is not coming over, nor will he ever come.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Are you sure of that?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: Very sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Then keep it a secret—don't tell her so—poor thing! it would break her heart. She is dotingly fond of her father.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: Hah! how!—oh no, she can have no re∣membrance of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Not of his person, perhaps: but he has con∣stantly corresponded with her; sent her presents, and affec∣tionate letters—and you know a woman's heart is easily im∣pressed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: I never heard her mention her father.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Not to you—but to us who are kind to her, she talks of him continually. She cried bitterly the other day when the last ship came in, and there was no account of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: Did she? did she? (eagerly.) Aye, I sup∣pose she is alarmed lest he should be dead, and all his fortune lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: No, I believe her affection for him is totally unconnected with any interested view I have watched her upon that head, and I believe she loves her father sincerely.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: (wiping a tear from his eye.) I believe it does not matter whom she loves!

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: By the bye, she hates you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: I thought so.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Yes you may be satisfied of that. Yes, she even quarrelled with me the other day for speaking in your favour: you had put her in a passion, and she said "no one that lov'd , ought to have any spect for you."

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: I am much obliged to her—very much obliged to her. Did she say nothing more?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Only "that you were ill-natured, dogmatic, cruel, and inso ent." Nothing more.—And say what she will against you, you know you can be even with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Yes, I can be even with her, and I will even with her.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lord Priory, and takes Bronzely on one side.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: I have accepted this man's apology.—I will not call him to a serious account; but he shall not escape every kind of resentment. I am resolved to laugh at him; to turn the whole affair into mirth and good humour; and at the same time to him to the heart. Good morning, Mr. Man∣dred—how do you do this morning, Mr. Mandred?—Let me go (violently to Bronzely) I must joke with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: But neither your voice nor your looks agree with your words.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Mr. Mandred, I did not intend to be angry—but it would give too respectable an air to a base action—and so I am come to laugh at you. [Enter Lady Mary.] And I am sure, you, Lady Mary, will join even me, in laughing at this man of gallantry.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Oh, I am absolutely afraid to come near the Tarquin!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: You need not, Lady Mary; for there can be no Tarquin without a Lucretia.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: However, Mr. Mandred, it is proper I should tell you, I accept the apology you have made: but at the same time—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm
SP.P: [hastily.] What do you mean, my Lord? I have made no apology.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Yes, yes, you have—I called and made one for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Made an apology for me! You have just gone one step too far then; and I insist—

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely
SP.P: [Drawing Sir William on one side.] I will—I will set every thing to rights. It would be base in me if I did not; and I will. (Turns to Lord Priory and Lady Mary.) Yes, Mr▪ Mandred, I will retrieve your character at the ex∣pence of my own. I am more able to contend with the frenzy of a jealous husband than you are—(Enter Miss Dorril on and Sir George Evelyn.)—I am happy to see —you are just come in time to hear me clear the grave, pectable character of my friend Mr. Mandred, and ise my own.—My Lord, vent all your anger an upon me. It was I [pray believe me, I beg you will; n't doubt my word], it was I who committed the offence of which my friend, the man I respect and reverence, stands accused—It was I who offended my Lady Priory, and then—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: It can't be—I won't believe you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: But how generous and noble in him to take it upon himself!

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely
SP.P: (to Sir William.) There! what can I do more? You see they won't believe me!—Tell me what I can do more? Can I do any thing more?—My feelings are wounded on your account, more than on m own, and compel me, though reluctantly, to quit the room.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: I am at a oss which to admire most, the warmth of Mr. Bronzely's friendship, or the coldness Mr. Mandred's gratitude!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary
SP.P: Oh! if it were not for that happy steadiness of feature, he could not preach rectitude of conduct as he does.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory
SP.P: (going up to Sir William.) Eloquent admo∣nisher of outh!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: (going to him.) Indeed, my rigid monitor, I cannot but express admiration, that, under those austere looks, and that sullen brow, there still shoud urk—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Have a care—don't proceed—stop where you are—dare not you complete a sentence that is meant to mock me.—I have borne the impertinence of this whole com∣pany with patience, with contempt; but dare you to breathe an accent suspicios of my conduct, and I wil instantl teach you how to respect me, and to shrink with horror from your∣self.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: What a passion he is in! Compose your∣self, Mr. Mandred.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: I protest, Mr. Mandred—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Silence. (Raising his voice.) Dare not to ad∣dress yourself to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Did you ever hear the like?—And I ow she looks awed by him!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: How strange, that a man can't command his temper!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Mr. Mandred, permit me to say, I have ever wish to treat you with respect—nor would be rash in laying that wish aside.—Yet, I must now take upon me to assure you, that if you think to offend every lady in this house with impity, you are mistaken.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Sir George, if you mean to frighten me by your threats, I'll laugh at you—but if your warmth is really kind∣led, and by an attachment to that unworthy object, (pointing to Miss Dorrillon) I oy pity you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Insufferable!—(going up to him.)—Instantly make an atonement for what you have said, or expect the consequence!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: And pray, Sir George, what atonement does your justice demand?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Retract your words—Acknowledge you were grossly deceived when you said Miss Dorrillon was unworthy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Retract m words!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Were they not unjust?—Is it a reproach, that, enveloped in the maze of fashionable life, she has yet preserved her virtue unsuspected? That, encumbered with the expences consequent to her connections, she has proudly disdained even from me the honourable offer of pecuniary aid? that her fond hope still fixes on the return of an absent parent, whose blessing she impatiently expects? and that I shoud have watched her whole conduct with an eye of scru∣tinizing jealousy, and yet have only beheld that which makes me aspire, as the summit of earthly happiness, to become her husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Young man, I admire your warmth (with great fervour and affection) There is much compassion, and be∣nevolence, and charity, in sometimes mistaking the vicious for the virtuous;—and if in the heat of contention I have said a word reflecting on your character, I am ready to avow my error; and before this company to beg your pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: That is not enough, Sir—(taking Miss Dor∣rillon by the hand, and leading her forwar—you must ask this lady's pardon.
SP.STAGE: (Sir William starts, and turns his face away, strongly im∣pressed.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Ask her pardon! Though I forgive some insults I will not this.—Ask her pardon?—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Nay, nay, sir George, you have no business with Mr. Mandred's quarrels and mine—Reserve your heroic courage for some nobler purpose than a poor woman▪s reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Point out a nobler, and I'll give up this.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: There is none so noble? And I wish Sir George you would undertake to vindicate mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Come, Lady Mary, let us retire, and leave these two irritable men to themselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Come, Maria, let us leave them alone. He'll teach Mr. Mandred to be civil for the future.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: (in great agitation) Dear madam, I would not leave them a one for the world!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Then my Lord, you and I will; they have no offensive weapons; so we may venture to leave them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: This comes of being too warm in conver∣sation! This comes of being in a passion!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: While there is a female present, I have only to say—good morning, Mr. Mandred▪

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor
SP.P: (catching hold of him▪) For once I give up my pride to soften yours. Come, do not ook thus determined?—I am sure Mr▪ Mandred did not mean to offend me; the words he made use of fell from his lips by accident.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: They did not—I meant them—I mean them still—and I repeat them

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: (to Sir William) Now how can you be so provoking?—Nay, hold Sir George, (he offers to go) you shall not go away with that frowning brow. (She draws him gently towards Sir William, then takes Sir William's hand) Nor you, with yours—Come shake hands for my sak.—Now, as I live, Sir George, Mr. Mandred's hand fees war∣mer and kinder than yours—he tries to draw it back, but he has not the heart. (Sir William snatches it away as by compul∣sion.)—Thou art a strange personage!—thou wilt not suffer me either to praise or to dispraise thee—Come Sir George, make up this difference—for if you were to ight, and Mr. Mandred was to fall—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: What then?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Wh, "I could better spare a better man."

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: I see you are both sulen both obstinate, and I have but one resource—Sir George, if you aspire to my hand, dare not to ift yours against Mr. Mandred He and I profess to be enemies; but if may judge of his feelings by my own, we have but passing enmities—bear him no maice, nor he me, I dare be sworn▪ Therefore Sir, lit but your arm against him, or insult him with another word, and our intercourse is for ever at an end▪

DIV3.STAGE: (Sir George and Sir William stand for some time silent)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Why is it in the power of one woman to make two men look ridiculously?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: I am at a loss to know, Sir, whether you and I part friends or enemies—However, cal on me in the way you best like, and you will find me ready to meet you either as an enemy, or as a friend, (Exeunt separately.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. A Hall at Lord Priory's.

SP.SPEAKER: First Serv.
SP.P: —Do you hear, Mr. Porter, you are to admit no person but Mr. Bronzely.

SP.SPEAKER: Second Serv.
SP.P: Mr. Bronzely—very well—(a loud rap∣ping)—and there I suppose he is.

SP.SPEAKER: First Servant,
SP.P: looking through the window. Yes; that I be∣lieve is his carriage—(to Third Servant)—Let my ady know.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Bronzely.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: You are sure lady Priory is at home?

SP.SPEAKER: First Serv
SP.P: —Yes, Sir, and gave orders to admit nobody but you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Has she been some time at home?

SP.SPEAKER: First Serv.
SP.P: —Yes, Sir; I dare say my lady came from Mr. Norberry's half an hour ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Waiting for me half an hour—(aside)—Shew me her instantly.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II. An Apartment at Lord Priory's.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Bronzely and Lady Priory on opposite sides.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: My dear lady Priory, how kind you are not to have forgotten your promise

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: How was it possible should? I have been so anxious for the intelligence ou have to communicate, that it was pain to wait till the time arrived.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Thus invited, encouraged to speak, I will speak boldly—and I can heaven to witness, that what I am going to sa—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: No, stay a moment onger—don't tell me just yet—(listening towards the side of the scenes)—for I wish him to hear the very beginning.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Who, hear the very beginning?

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lord Priory—Bronzely starts.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: I have not kept you waiting, hope. My lawyer stopt me on business, or I should have been here sooner. My dear Mr. Bronzely (going up to him) thank you a thou∣sand times for the interest you take in my concerns; and I come prepared with proper cooness and composure to hear the secret with which you are going to entrust us

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely▪
SP.P: The secret!—yes, Sir—The secret which I was going to disclose to my lady Priory—Ha, ha, ha!—But, my lord, I am afraid it is of too frivolous a nature for your attention.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: I account nothing frivolous which concerns my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Certainly, my Lord, certainly not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Besides, she told me it was of the utmost importance. Did not you? (angrily.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: He said so.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: And so it was—it was of importance then—just at the very time I was speaking to Lady Priory on the subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: You said so but this very moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Come, come, tell it immediately, what∣ever it is. Come, let us hear it.—(after waiting some time) Why, Sir, you look as if you were ashamed of it? What can be the meaning of this?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: To be plain, my lord, my secret will disclose the folly of a person for whom I have a sincere regard.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: No matter—let every fool look like a fool, and every villain be known for what he is—Tell your story.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: How can you deprive me of the pleasure you promised? You said it would prevent every future care.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Explain, Sir. I begin to feel myself not quite so composed as I expected. You never, perhaps, saw me in a passion—she has—and if you were once to see me really angry—

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely,
SP.P: Then, my lord, I am apt to be passionate too—and I boldly tell you, that what I had to reveal, tho' per∣fectly proper, was meant for lady Priory alone to hear. I en∣treated your ladyship not to mention to my lord that I had any thing to communicate, and you gave me a solemn promise you would not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Upon my honour, during our whole con∣versation upon that subject, you never named my lord Priory's name.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: I charged you to keep what I had to tell you a profound secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Yes; but I thought you understood I could have no secrets from my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: You promised no one should know it but yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: He is myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P:
How, Mr. Bronzely, did you suppose she and I were two? Perhaps you did, and that we wanted a third. Well, I quite forgive you for your sily mistake, and laugh at you, ha, ha, ha, as I did at Mr. Mandred (seri∣ously—Did you suppose, sir, we lived like persons of fashion of the modern ? Did you imagine that a woman of her
character could have a wish, a desire, even a thought, a se∣cret from her husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: It is amazing to find so much fidelity the re∣ward of tyranny!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Sir—I speak with humility—I would not wish to give offence—(timidly)—But to the best of my obser∣vation and understanding, your sex, in respect to us, are all tyrants. I was born to be the slave of some of you—I make the choice to obey my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Yes, Mr. Bronzely; and I believe it is more her happiness to be my slave, than your friend—to live in fear of me, than in love with you—Lady Priory, leave the room.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Do you see—did you observe the glow of truth and candour which testifies that woman's faith? and do you not blush at having attempted it? Call me a tyrant! Where are the signs? Oh, if every married man would follow my system in the management of his wife, every impertinent lo∣ver would look just as foolish as you!

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: This is all boasting, my lord—you live in con∣tinual fear—for (without meaning any offence to lady Priory's honour) you know you dare not trust her one hour alone with any man under sixty.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: I dare trust her at any time with a coxcomb.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely▪
SP.P: That is declaring I am not one—for I am cer∣tain you dare not trust her alone with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory
SP.P: (in a passion) Yes, with fifty such.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: But not with one—and you are right, it might be dangerous.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory
SP.P: (angrily) No, it would not.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: (significantly) Yes, it would.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Have not you had a trial?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: But you were present. You constantly follow all her steps, watch all she says and does. But I believe you are right—wives are not to be trusted.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Mine is.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: No, my dear lord Priory, you must first be∣come gentle, before you can positively conide in her affection—before you can trust her in a house, or in any place, one.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory
SP.P: (hastily) To prove you are mistaken, I'll in∣stantly go back to my friend Norberry's, and leave you here to tell her the secret you boasted. Pay your addresses to her, if that is the secret—you have my free conent.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: My dear friend, I'll accept it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Ay, I see you have hopes of supplanting me, by calling me your friend—But can you conceive now that she'll listen to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: You have given me leave to try, and can't recal it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: But depend upon it, you will meet with some terrible humiliation.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Either you or I shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: I shall laugh to hear you tumbled down stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: You are not to remain on the watch here; you are to return to Mr. Norberry's.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Was that the bargain?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Don't you remember? You said so.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Well, if that will give you any satisfaction—

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: It will give me great satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Heaven forgive me, but your confidence makes me laugh. Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: And your's makes me laugh.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Oliver.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Hah! What brings you here, Oliver? Lady Priory and I are only come home for a few hours.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: I know it, my Lord. I thought nevertheless I might be wanted.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: And so you are, good Mr. Oliver. Your Lord desires you to conduct me to your Lady in the next room, and acquaint her it is with his permission I am come to conclude the conversation which was just now interrupted—Is not that right, my Lord? Are not those words exactly correspond∣ing with your kind promise?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: I believe they are.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
