SP.P: I am "to take Mr. Bronzely to my Lady, and tell her you sent him"

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Now this is perfect fashion; and while I step to Lady Priory, do you go and comfort my intended wife, Lady Mary.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: I hate the fashion—and were I not sure you would now be received in a very unfashionable manner—

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: No rough dealings, I hope?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Oh, you begin to be afraid, do you?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: No—but I have met with an accident or two lately—and I am not so well acquainted with ancient usages as to know in what manner a man of my pursuits would have been treated in former times.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: A man of your pursuits. Mr. Bronzely, is of a very late date; and to be shamed out of them by a wife like mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Then we shall all three be old-fashioned.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory
SP.P: (returning and looking anxiously after Bron.) I am passionate—I am precipitate—I have no command over my temper.—However, if a man cannot govern himself, yet he will never make any very despicable figure, as long as he knows how to govern his wife.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III. Sir Wm.'s Apartment at Mr. Norberry's.—Se∣veral trunks and travelling-boxes.—Sir Wm. discovered, packing writings into a port-folio.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: And here is the end of my voyage to England!—a voyage, which for years, my mind has dwelt on with delight!—I pictured to myself my daughter grown to wo∣manhood, beautiful! and so she is.—Accomplished! and so she is.—Virtuous! and so she is.—Am I of a discontented nature then, that I am not satisfied?—Am I too nice?—Per∣haps I am.—Soothing thought!—I will for a moment cherish it, and dwell with some little gratitude upon her late anxiety for my safety. [He walks about in a thoughtful musing manner.

P.HI: A loud thrusting and rapping is heard at his chamber door.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Miss Dor. hastily and in affright.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Oh Mr. Mandred, I beg your pardon—I did not know this was your apartment. But suffer me to lock the door: [she locks it] and conceal me for a moment, for heaven's sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: What's the matter? Why have you locked my door?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: [trembling]. I dare not tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: I insist upon knowing.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Why then—I am pursued by a—I cannot name the horrid name—

SP.SPEAKER: Nabson
SP.P: (without.) She went into this room.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: (to Sir Wm.) Go to the door, and say I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Nabson
SP.P: [without.] Please to open the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Threaten to beat him if he won't go away.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Give me the key, and let me see from whom you want to hide.—[commandingly]—Give me the key.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: [collecting firmness.] I will not.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: [starting.] "Will not"—"Will not", when I desire you!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: No—since you refuse me protection, I'll pro∣tect myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: But you had better not have made use of that expression to me—you had better not. Recal it by giving me the key.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: If I do, will you let me conceal myself behind that book-case, and say I am not here?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Utter a falsehood?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: I would for you. [A hammering at the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: They are breaking open the door.—Give me the key, I command you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: "Command me!" "command me!" How∣ever there it is. [Gives it him.] And now, if you are a gen∣tleman, give me up if you dare!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: "If I am a gentleman!" Hem, hem—"If I am a gentleman!" "Dares" me too!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Yes. I have now thrown myself upon your protection: and if you deliver me to my enemies—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: What enemies? What business have you with enemies?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: 'Tis they have business with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: [to them without.] I am coming. The door shall be opened.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: [follows and lays hold of him.] Oh, for heaven's sake, have pity on me—they are merciless creditors—I shall be dgged to a prison. Do not deliver me up—I am unfortunate—I am overwhelmed with misfortune—have compassion on me! (She falls on her knees.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: (in great agitation) Don't kneel to me!—I don't mean you to kneel to me!—What makes you think of kneeling to me?—I must do my duty. (He unlocks the door.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Nabson—Miss Dorrillon steals behind the book-case.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: What did you want, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Nabson.
SP.P: lady, that I have just this minute made my prisoner; but she ran from me, and ocked herself in here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: [with surprise.] Aested a ady!

SP.SPEAKER: Nabson.
SP.P: Yes, Sir; and if ou mean to deny her being here, I must make bold to search the room.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Let me look at your credents—(takes the writ)—"Elizabeth Dorrillon for six hundred pounds." Pray sir, is it customary to have female names on pieces of paper of this denomination?

SP.SPEAKER: Nabson.
SP.P: Oh, yes, sir, very customary. There are as many ladies who will run into tradesmen's books, as there are gentlemen; and when one goes to take the ladies, they are a thousand times more slippery to catch than the men.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Abominable▪—Well sir, your present prisoner shall not slip through your hands, if I can prevent it. I scorn to defend a worthess woman, as much as I should glory in preserving a good one and I give myself joy in being the instrument of your executing justice—[He goes and ads Miss Dorrillon from the place where she was concealed—she casts down her head]—What! do you droop? Do you tremble? You, who at the ball to-night would have danced lightly, though your poor creditor had been perishing with want! You who never asked yourself if your extravagance might not send an industrious father of a family to prison, can you feel on the prospect of going thither yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: For what cause am I the object of your perpe∣tual persecution?

SP.SPEAKER: Nabson.
SP.P: Lor! Madam, the gentleman means to bail you after all: I can see it by his looks.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: How, rascal, dare you suppose, or imagine, or hint, such a thing? [going up to him in anger.]

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: That's right, beat him out of the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: No, Madam, he shall not go out of the house without taking you along with him. Punishment may effect in your disposition what indulgence has no hope of produ∣cing.—There's your prisoner [handing her over to him]—and you may take my word, that she will not be released by me, or by any one: and it will be only adding to a debt she can never pay, to take her to any place previous to a prison. (with the emotion of resentment, yet deep sorrow.)

SP.SPEAKER: Nabson.
SP.P: Is that true, my lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor▪
SP.P: (after a pause) Very true. I have but one friend—but one relation in the world—and he is far away.

SP.SPEAKER: Nabson.
SP.P: More's the pity.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: No, sir, no—no pity at all—for if fewer ine ladies had friends, we should have fewer examples of profli∣gacy. (She walks to the door, then turns to Sir William.)

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: I forgive you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William
SP.P:
(looking after her.) And perhaps I could for∣give you. But I must not. No, this is justice—this is doing
my duty—this is strength of mind—this is fortitude—forti∣tude—fortitude. (He walks proudly across the n, then stops, takes out his handkerchief, throws his head into it, and is going off.)

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lady Mary—a man following at a distance.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Mr. Mandred, Mr. Mandred. (He turns.) Sir—Mr. Mandred—Sir—(in a suppcating tone) I pre∣sume—I presume, sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: What, Madam? what?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: I came, sir, to request a favour of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: So it should seem, b that novel deportment.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: If you would for once consi with lenity, frailty incidental to a woman who lives in the gay world—the

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Well, Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: How much she is led away by the tempta∣tion of fine cloaths, fine coaches, and fine things.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Come to the business.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: You are rich, we all know, though you en∣deavour to disguise the truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: I can't stay to hear you, if you don't proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: My request is—save from the dreadful hor∣rors of a jail, a woman who has no friend near her—a woman who may have inadvertenty offended you, but who never—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: it is in vain for you to plead on her account—she knows my sentiments upon her conduct—she knows the opi∣nion I have formed of her—and you cannot prevail on me to change it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Do you suppose I come to plead fo Miss Dor.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Certainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: No, I am pleading for myself. I am un∣fortunately involved in similar circumstances—I have a similar debt to the self-same tradesman, and we are both at present in the self-same predicament.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: And upon what pretence did you suppose I would be indulgent to you, more than to her?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Because you have always treated me with less severity; and because overheard o just now say, you "should glory in delivering from difficulty a good woman."

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: And so I should

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: How unlike the world!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P:
No—whatever the discontented may please to say, the world is affectionate, is generous, to the good; more especially to the good of the female sex; for it is only an ex∣ception
to a general rule, when a good woman is in pecuniary distress.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lord Priory, humming a tune, but with a very serious face: he pulls out his watch with evident marks of anxiety—coughs—rubs his forehead—and gives various other marks of discontent and agitation.—Lady Mary observes him with attention, then sidles up to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: By the good humour you appear in, my lord, I venture to mention to you my distresses. know the virtues of lady Priory makes my faiings conspicuous; but then con∣sider the different modes to which we have been habituated—she excluded from temptation—.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: No—she shuns temptation. Has she not in this very house been compelled to make exertions? Has she not detected and exposed both Mr. Mandred and Mr. Bron.?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Bronzely! Bronzely! How! (Aside. A∣nother rival?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: He has not done with him yet, I believe; for to tell the truth, he is now with her at my house in Park∣street. He taxed me with being jealous of my wife—To prove in what contempt I held the accusation, I left them to∣gether, and bid him make love to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Is that possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: I can't say I would have done so rash an action, had I been married to some women—to you, for in∣stance—but I have not a doubt of Lady Priory's safety: her mind, I know, is secure, and I have servants in the house to protect her from persona outrage. The only fear is, lest he should have received one; for 'tis now near two hours (looking at his watch) since I came away, and I have neither seen nor heard any thing of either of them!—But to your lad ships concerns▪

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary▪
SP.P: I am at this instant, my lord, in the power of an implacable creditor; and without a friend who will give bond for a certain sum, must—I bush to name it—be taken to a prison

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: I am not at all surprised at the circumstance, Madam: but it amazes me that you should apply to me for de∣liverance. You have a brother in town; why not send to him?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: He was my friend the very last time a dis∣tress of this kind befel me. (Weeps.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Ask Mr. Norberry.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: He was my friend the time before.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Mr. Bronzely, then.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: And Bronzely the time before that.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Oliver.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Ah, Oliver! I am glad to see you, my good fellow. Ha! what have you done with Mr. Bronzely?

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Nay, my lord, that I can't tell. I can't tell what he has done with himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: How long has he been gone from my house?

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: He is not gone yet as I know of; for none of the servants let him out.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Not gone! and you can't tell where he is!

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: No, that we can't: we have looked in every room for him, and can't find him any where.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Not find him! (recollecting himself) Ho! ho! I thought how it would be—I thought he'd have some trick played him. Where's your lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: That I can't tell neither. We have looked in every room, and can't find her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: 'Tis as sure as I am alive. I and the butler, two footmen, and all the maids, have been looking in parlours, chambers, and garrets, every crick and corner, and no where can we find either Mr. Bronzely or my lady; but, wherever they are, there's no doubt but they are together. Ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! No doubt at all, Mr. Oliver.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Together! together! and not in my house! You tell a falsehood I'll go myself and find them.

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: You must look sharp, then.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: How came you to miss them?

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: I chanced to go into the next room, to see if there was a proper ire to get it well aired; I knew I had taken Mr. Bronzely to my Lady in the inner room, and I had heard them both laughing not a quarter of an hour before; but now, al on a sudden, there was neither laughing nor talking, nor any noise at all—every thing was so quiet, you might have heard a pin drop.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory
SP.P: (anxiously.) Well

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: And so I thought to myself, thought I, I'll sit down here; for my ad will be ringing soon: however, there was no ringing for a whole half hour; and so then I thought I would e'en rap at the door; but nobody called "Come in." So then I went in of my own accord; and there I found—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: Nobody! not a soul to be seen!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord, Priory
SP.P: (affecting indifference.) Oh! she has been playing Bronzely some trick! She has been hiding him; and in some miserable place!

SP.SPEAKER: Oliver.
SP.P: But why need she hide herself along with him?

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mr. Norberry.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr.Norberry.
SP.P: My dear friend, my dear lord Priory, let me speak with you alone.—I come upon business that—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: You look pale! What is your business? Tell it me at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr.Norberry.
SP.P: It is of so delicate a nature—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: I know my wife is with Mr. Bronzely—I left them together. I know he is a licentious man; but I know she is an innocent woman.—Now, what have you to tell me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Norberry.
SP.P: What I have just learnt from one of your servants. About a quarter of an hour after you left them, they stole softly out at the back of your house, ran to a post∣chaise and four that was in waiting, and drove off together full speed.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Gone! eloped! run away from me! left me! left the tenderest, kindest, most indulgent husband, that ever woman had!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: That we can all witness.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: I was too fond of her—my affection ruin∣ed her—women are ungrateful—I did not exert a husband's authority—I was not strict enough—I humoured and spoiled her!—Bless me! what a thick mist is come over my eyes!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: No, my Lord, it is clearing away.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Lead me to my room. (He is led off by Mr. Nor.exhausted with grief and anger.)—Oliver looks after Lord Priory, then takes out his handkerchief, and follows him off crying.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! Oh, how I enjoy this distress▪ Ha, ha, ha!
SP.STAGE: The officer who has attended her during the scene, and kept at the farther part of the stage, now comes forward, and bows to her. She starts on seeing him—takes out her handkerchief, and goes crying off at the opposite side.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. An Apartment at Bronzely's.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Housekeeper and Footman.

SP.SPEAKER: Hous.
SP.P:
Dinner enough for twelve, and only two to sit
down to it! Come home without one preparation—not a bed aired, or the furniture uncovered.

SP.SPEAKER: Foot.
SP.P: This is not the first time he has done so.

SP.SPEAKER: Hous.
SP.P: No; but it's always thus when a woman's in the case. Well, I do say that my own sex are—

SP.SPEAKER: Foot.
SP.P: Hush! here they are. Run away.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lady Priory and Mr. Bronzely.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Only twelve miles from London?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: No more, be assured.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: And you avow that I did not come hither by the commands of my husband, but was deceived into that belief by you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Still it was by his commands your servant intro∣duced me to you; and, upon an errand, which I feared to deliver till I arrived at a house of my own.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: What is the errand?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: To tell you that—I love you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Do you assert, lord Priory sent you to me for this?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: I assert, that, in triumph at your betraying to him our private appointment, he gave me leave to have a se∣cond trial. If, then, you have ever harboured one wish to revenge, and forsake a churlish ungrateful partner, never re∣turn to him more—but remain with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: And what shall I have gained by the ex∣change, when you become churlish, when you become ungrate∣ful? My children's shame! the worlds contempt! and yours! (Smiling) Come, come; you are but jesting, Mr. Bronzely! You would not affront my little share of com∣mon sense by making the serious offer of so bad a bargain. Come own the jest, and take me home immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Is it impossible for me to excite your tenderness?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Utterly impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: I will then rouse your terror.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Even that I defy.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Lady Priory, you are in a lonely house of mine, where I master, and all the servants slaves to my will.
SP.STAGE: (Lady Priory calmly takes out her knitting, draws a chair, and sits down to knit a pair of lockings.)

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely
SP.P: (aside.) This composure is worse than reproach—a woman who meant to yield would be outrageous.—(Goes to speak to her, then turns away.) By heaven she looks so res∣pectable in that employment, I am afraid to insult her. (Af∣ter a struggle with himself.) Ah! don't you fear me?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: No—for your fears will protect me—I have no occasion for my own.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: What have I to fear?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Your fear to lounge no more at routs, at bals, at operas, in Bond-street; no more to dance in circles, chat in sde boxes, or roar at taverns: for you have observed enough upon the events of life to know—that an atrocious offence like violence to a woman, never escapes condign punish∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Oh! for once, let your mind be feminine as your person—hear the vows—
SP.STAGE: (he seizes her hand—she rises—he starts back)

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Ah! did not I tell you, you were afraid? 'Tis you who are afraid of me. (He looks abashed.) Come, you are ashamed, too—I see you are, and I pardon you.—In requital, suffer me to return home immediately. (He shakes his head.]—How! are not you ashamed of yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: I was not this moment—But now you men∣tion it, I think I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Repent your foly then, and take me home. (hastily).

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Can you wish to go back to the man who has made this trial of your fidelity, and not resent his conduct?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Most assuredly I wish to return. But if you deliver me safe, perfectly safe from farther insult, it will be impossible for me not to shew resentment to Lord Priory.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Why only in that case?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Because, only in that case, you will make an impression on m heart—and I will resent his having expo∣sed me to such a temptation.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Oh! I'll take you home directly—this moment.—I make an impression on your heart. William!—(calling)—I'll take you home directly. Here John, Thomas, Wil∣liam—(calling) But, upon my life, it would be a hard task—I cannot do it—I am afraid—I am afraid I cannot—Besides, what are we to say when we go back?—No matter what, so you will but think kindly of me. (Enter Servant.)—Order the horses to be put to the chaise; I am going back to London immediately. Quick! quick! Bid the man not be a moment, for fear I should change my mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: The chaise is ready now, Sir; for the post-boy was going back without unharnessing his horses.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P:
Then tell him he must perform his journey in
half an hour—If he is a moment longer, my resolution will stop on the road. (Exit Ser.) I feel my good designs steal∣ing away aread—now they are fling rapidly. (Taking Lady Priory's hand)—Please to look another way—I shall certainly recant if I see you. (Going)—And now should I have the resolution to take you straight to your husband, you will have made a more contemptible figure of me by this last trick, than by any one you have played me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: (Without) Tell the post-boy he need not wait—I have changed my mind—I shan't go to London to-night.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II. A Room in a Prison.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Miss Dorril on and Mr. Norberry.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: You ought to have known it was in vain to send for me. Have not I repeatedly declared, that, till I heard from your father, you should receive nothing more from me than a bare subsistence?—I promise to allow you thus much, even in this miserable place: but do not indulge a hope that I can release you from it. (She weeps—he goes to the door—then returns.) I forgot to mention, that Mr. Man∣dred goes on board to-morrow for India; and, little as you may think of his sensibility, he seems concerned at the thought of quitting England without just bidding you farewel. He came with me hither—shall I send him up?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Oh! no: for heaven's sake! Deliver me from his asperity, as you would save me from distraction.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: Nay, 'tis for the last time—you had better see him. You may be sorry, perhaps, you did not, when he is gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: No, no; I sha'nt be sorry.—Go and excuse me—Go, and prevent his coming. I cannot see him.—(Exit Mr. Norberry)—This would be aggravation of punishment, to shut me in a prison, and not shelter me from the insults of the world!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir William.—(She starts)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: —I know you have desired not to be troub∣led with my visit; and I come with all humility—I do not come, be assured, to reproach you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Unexpected mercy!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: No; though I have watched your course with anger, yet I do not behold its end, with triumph.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: It is not to your honour that you think it neces∣sary to give this statement of your mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: May be—but I never boasted of perfection, though I can boast of grief that I am so far beneath it. I can boast too, that, though I frequently give offence to others. I could never part with any one for ever (as I now shall with you), without endeavouring to make some atonement.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: You acknowledge, then, your cruelty to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: I acknowledge I have taken upon me to advise, beyond the liberty allowed by custom to one who has no ap∣parent interest or authority.—But, not to repeat what has passed, I come with the approbation of your friend Mr. Nor∣berry, to make a proposal to you for the future.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: What proposal?—What is it? [eagerly.]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Mr. Norberry will not give either his money or his word to release you—But as I am rich—have lost my only child—and wish to do some good with my fortune, I will in∣stantly lay down the money of which you are in want, upon certain conditions.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Do I hear right? Is it possible I can find a friend in you?—a friend to relieve me from the depth of misery! Oh Mr. Mandred!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Before you return thanks, hear the conditions on which I make the offer.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Any conditions—What you please!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: You must promise, never, never to return to your former follies and extragancies. (She looks down.) Do you hesitate? Do you refuse?—Won't you promise?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: I would, willingly—but for one reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: And what is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: The fear, I should not keep my word.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: You will, if your fear be real.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: It is real—It is even so great, that I have no hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: You refuse my offer then, and dismiss me? (rises.)

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: (rising also.) With much reluctance.—But I cannot, indeed I cannot make a promise, unless I were to feel my heart wholly subdued; and my mind entirely convinced that should never break it—Sir, I am most sincerely obliged to you for the good which I am sure you designed me; but do not tempt me with the proposal again—do not place me in a situation, that might add to all my other afflictions, the remorse of having deceived you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P:
(after a pause.) Well, I will dispense with
this condition—but there is another I must substitute in its stead.—Resolve to pass the remainder of your life, some few ensuing years at least, in the country. (She starts.) Do you start at that?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: I do not love the country. I am always mi∣serable while I am from London. Besides, there are no fol∣lies or extravagancies in the country.—Dear Sir, this is giv∣ing me up the first condition, and then forcing me to keep it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: There, Madam, (taking out his pocket-book) I scorn to hold out hopes, and then destroy them. There is a thousand pounds free of all conditions (she takes it)—extri∣cate yourself from this situation, and be your own mistress to return to it when you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Oh, my benefactor, bid me farewell at part∣ing—do not leave me in anger.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: How! will you dictate terms to me, while you reject al mine?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Then only suffer me to express my gratitude—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: I will not hear you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Then hear me on another subject: a subject of much importance—indeed it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Well!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: You are going to India immediately—It is possible that there, or at some place you will stop at on your way, you may meet with my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Well!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: You have heard that I have expected him home for some time past, and that I still live in hopes.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Well!—(anxiously)

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: If you should see him, and should be in his company—don't mention me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Not mention you?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: At least, not my indiscretions—Oh! I should die, if I thought he would ever know of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Do you think he would not discover them him∣self, should he ever see you?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: But he would not discover them all at once—I should be on my guard when he first came—My ill habits would steal on him progressively, and not be half so shocking, as if you were to vociferate them all in a breath.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: To put you out of apprehension at once—your father is not coming home—nor will he ever return to his own country.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: You seem to speak from certain knowledge—Oh! heavens! is he not living?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Yes, living—but under severe affliction—fortune has changed, and all his hopes are blasted.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor
SP.P: "Fortune has changed!"—In povert?—my father in poverty?—(weeing)—Oh▪ Sir▪ excuse, what may perhaps appear an ill compiment to your bounty; but to me, the greatest reverence I can pay to it.—You are going to that part of the world where he is; take this precious gift back, search out my father and let him be the object of your beneficence.—[Forces it into his hand.]—I shall be happy in this prison, indeed shall, so can but give a momentary relief to my dear, dear father.—[Sir William takes out his handker∣chief]—You weep:—This present, perhaps, would be but poor alleviation of his sufferings—perhaps he is in sickness; or a prisoner: Oh! if he is release me instantly, and take me with you to the place of his confinement.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: What! quit the joys of London?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: On such an errand, I would quit them all without a sigh—And here I make a solemn promise to you—(kneeling.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm▪
SP.P: Hold, you may wish to break it.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Never—exact what vow you will on this oc∣casion, will make, and keep it.—[Enter Mr. Norberry.—She rises.]—Oh! Mr Norberry, he has been telling me such things of my father—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: Has he? Then kneel again—call him by that name—and implore him not to disown you for his child.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Good heaven!—I dare not—I dare not do as you require. [She faints on Norberry.]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: (going to her) My daughter!—My child!—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: At those names she revives.—(She raises her , but expresses great agitation.)—Come, let us quit this wretched place—she will be better then. My carriage is at the door. You will follow us.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: Follow you!—Yes—and I perceive that, in spite of philosophy, justice, or resolution, I could follow you all the world over.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III. Another Room in the Prison.
DIV3.STAGE: Lady Mary discovered sitting in a dejected posture, at a mi∣serable table.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P:
Provoking not an answer to one of my
pathetic letters!—no a creature to come and condole with me!—Oh that could but regain my liberty before my dis∣grace is announced in the public prints—I could then boldly contradict every paragraph that asserted it—by We have authority to say, no such event ever took pace.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter a Man belonging to the prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: One Sir George Eveyn is here, Madam; he will not name your name, because it sha'n't be made public; but he desires you will permit him to come and speak a few words to you, provided ou are the young lady from Grosvenor-street, with whom he has the pleasure of being acquainted.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I am the young lady from Gros∣venor-street—my compliments to Sir George, I am that lady; intimately acquainted with him; and entreat he will wak up. (Exit the Man.) This is a most fortunate incident in my tragedy! Sir George no doubt takes me for Miss Dorrillon; yet I am sure he is too much the man of gallantry and good breeding to eave me in this pace, although he visits me by mistake.
SP.STAGE: Sir George Evelyn (speaking as he enters)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Madam, you are free—the doors of the pri∣son are open—my word is passed for the—[He stops—looks around—expresses surprise and confusion.]

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: (curtsying very low) Sir George, I am under the most infinite obligation!—Words are too poor to convey the sense I have of this act of friendship—but trust my gratitude will for ever—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George
SP.P: (confuse.) Madam—really—I ought to apo∣logise for the libert I have taken.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: No liberty at all, Sir George—at least no apology is necessary—I insist on hearing no excuses. A vir∣tuous action requires no preface, no prologue, no ceremony—and surely, if one action be more noble and generous than another, it must be that one, where an act of benevolence is conferred, and the object, an object of tota indifference to the libera benefactor—Generous man, good evening—Call me a coach.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Stay, Madam—I beg leave to say—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: —Not a word—I won't hear a word—my thanks shall drown whatever you have to say.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter the former Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Pray, Sir, did not you tell me, you had a very young lady under your care?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, so I had—but she, it seems, has just been released, and is gone away with the gentleman who paid the debt

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Do you mean Miss Dorrillon?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: I mean the other lady from Grosvenor-street.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Who can have released her?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Some friend of mine, I dare say, by mis∣take—Well, if it is so, she is extremely welcome to the good fortune which was designed for me. For my part, I could not submit to an obligation from every one—scarcely from any one—and from no one with so little regret as I submit to it from Sir George Evelyn.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Distraction! the first disappointment is nothing to this second! to the reflection that Miss Dorrillon has been set at liberty by any man on earth except myself.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV. An Apartment at Mr. Norberry's.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lord Priory

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: What a situation is mine! I cannot bear so∣litude, and am ashamed to see company! I cannot bear to think on the ungrateful woman, and yet I can think of nothing else! t was her conduct which I imagined had alone charmed me; but I perceive her power over my heart, though that conduct is changed!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mr. Norberry, Sir William, and Miss Dorrillon.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Nor.
SP.P: My dear Lord Priory, exert our spirits to re∣ceive and congratulate a friend of mine. Sir William Dor∣rillon (presenting him) father to this young woman, whose failings he has endeavoured to correct under the borrowed name of Mandred.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: And with that fictitious name, I hope to disbur∣then myself of the imputation of having ever offered an af∣front to my lord Priory. (He takes Lord Priory aside, and they talk together.)

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir George Evelyn.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Is it possible what have heard is true? was it Mr. Mandred who has restored Miss Dorrillon to the pro∣tection of Mr. Norberry?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: (coming forward.) No, Sir George, I have now taken her under my own protection.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: By what tite, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: A very tender one—don't be alarmed—I am her father.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: Sir Wm. Dorrillon? (They talk apart.)

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lady Mary.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Has there been any intelligence of my Lady Priory yet? (sees Miss Dorrillon) My dear Dorrillon, a lover of yours has done the civilest thing by me!—As I live, here he is. How do you do, Sir George? I suppose you have all heard the news of Bronzely running away with—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Hush!—Lord Priory is here.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Oh, he knows it—and it is not improper to remind him of it—it will teach him humility.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory▪
SP.P: I am humble, Lady Mary, and own I have had a better opinion of your sex than I ought to have had.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: You mean, of your management of us; of your instructions, restrictions, and corrections.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Servant.
SP.P: Lady Priory and Mr. Bronzely.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: What of them?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: They are here.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: I said she'd preserve her fidelity! Did not I always say so? Have I wavered once? Did I not always tell you all that she was only making game of Bronzely? Did I not tell you all so?

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Bronzely and Lady Priory.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Then, indeed, my Lord, you said truly; for I return the arrantest blockhead—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: I always said you would! But how is it? Where have you been? What occasion for a post-chaise? Instantly explain, or I shall forfeit that dignity of a husband, to which, in those degenerate times, I have almost an exclu∣sive right.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: To reistate you my Lord, in those honours, I accompany Lady Priory; and beg public pardon for the opinion I once publicly professed, of your want of influence over her affections.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Do you hear? Do you all hear? Lady Mary, do you hear?

Taking advantage of your permission to call on her, stratagem I induced her to quit your house, st re∣straint might there act as my enemy. But your authority, your prerogative your honour attached to her under my roof. She has held those rights sacred, and compelled even me to revere them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Do you all hear? I was sure it would turn out so!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: This is the first time I ever knew the gal∣lant's word taken for a woman's honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: I will take her own word—the tongue which for eleven years has never in the slightest instance de∣ceived me, I wil believe upon all occasions. My dear wife, boldly pronounce before this company that you return to me with the same affection and respect, and the self-same con∣tempt for this man—(to Bron.)—you ever had.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: She makes no answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Hush! Hush! She is going to speak.—(Another pause)—Why, why don't you speak?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Because I am at a loss what to say.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Hear, hear, hear—do you all hear?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Can you be at a loss to declare you hate Mr. Bronzely?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: I do not hate him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: I was sure it would turn out so.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Can you be at a loss to say you love me?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: She is at a loss.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: How! Don't you fear me?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: She speaks plaly to that question.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: You know I love truth—speak plainly to all their curiosity requires.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Since you command it then, my Lord—I confess that Mr. Bronzeley's conduct towards me has caused a kind of sentiment in my heart—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Hah! what?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: You must believe her—"she has told you truth for eleven years."

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: A sensation which—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Stop—any truth but this I could have borne—Reflect on what you are saying—Consider what you are do∣ing—Are these your primitive manners?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: I should have continued those manners, had I known none but primitive men. But to preserve ancient austerity, while, by my husband's consent. I am assailed by modern gallantry, would be the task of a sto, and not of hi female slave.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Do you hear? Do you all hear? My Lord, do you hear?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: I do—I do—and though the sound distracts me, I cannot doubt her word.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: It gives me excessive joy to hear you say so, because you will not then doubt me when I add—that gratitude, for his restoring me so soon to you is the only sentiment he has inspired.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: Then my management of a wife is right after all!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Norberry.
SP.P: Mr. Bronzely, as your present behaviour has in great measure atoned for your former actions, I will introduce to your acquaintance my friend Sir William Dor∣rillon.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely.
SP.P: Mandred, Sir William Dorrillon!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: And considering, Sir, that upon one or two occasions I have been honoured with your confidence—you will not be surprised, if the first command I lay upon my daughter, is—to take refuge from your pursuits, in the protec∣tion of Sir George Evelyn.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: And may I hope, Maria?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: No—I will instantly put an end to all your hopes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir▪ George.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wm.
SP.P: By raising you to the summit of your wishes. Alarmed at my severity, she has owned her readiness to be∣come the subject of a milder government.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George.
SP.P: She shall never repin at the election she has made.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Priory.
SP.P: But, Sir George, if you are a prudent man, you will fix your eyes on my little domestic state, and guard against a rebellion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Priory.
SP.P: Not the rigour of its laws has ever induced me to wish them abolished.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronzely
SP.P: Dear Lady, you have made me think with reverence on the matrimonial compact: and I demand of you, Lady Mary—if, in consequence of former overtures, I should establish a egal authority over you, and become your chief magistrate—would you submit to the same controul to which Lady Priory submits?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Mary.
SP.P: Any controul, rather than have no chief magistrate at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir George
SP.P: And what do you say to this?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Dor.
SP.P: Simply one sentence—A maid of the present day shall become a wife like those—of former times.

DIV1.HEAD: ADDRESS, WRITTEN BY MR. TAYLOR; SPOKEN BY MISS WALLIS.

L.HI: WELL, female critics, what's the sentence, say—
Can you with kindness treat this saucy play,
That gives to ancient dames the wreath of praise
And boldly censures those of modern days?
Bring us good husbands first, and, on my life,
For every one we'll shew as good a wife.
Whate'er the errors in the nuptial state,
Man sets th' example to his passive mate:
While all the virtues the proud sex can claim
From female influence caught the gen'rous flame.
Nay, though our gallant rulers of the main
With force resistless rush the pride of Spain;
'Tis Woman triumphs—that inspiring charm
With tenfold vigour nerves the hero's arm:
For King and Country though they nobly bleed,
The smile of Beauty is their dearest med.
And valiant tars should still be Beauty's care
Since 'its "the brave alone deserve the fair."

DIV1.HEAD: WIVES AS THEY WERE, AND MAIDS AS THEY ARE: A COMEDY,
DIV1.P: Performed at the London and Dublin Theatres with universal applause—and at Greenwich-street, New-York.
